Posts.Content: terri-c wrote: Hi all, I would like to talk about SE's, and I don't want to limit it to just "my" treatment, because I would like to hopefully find people with a similar situation, and am curious how they handled it. I have been on Faslodex/Xgeva combo since June 2014. I was relatively fine at first, minimal side effects. Went to Disney this time last year, had no issues. Since around March/April I have noticed a marked increase in side effect pain after treatment. I'm not talking about just the injection site, but to be honest, my rear is permanently sore now. The fatigue is pretty hefty, and the bone/joint/muscle pain has gotten really bad. When the pain started, I was given pain meds, but I don't like to take them: I don't like the way they make me feel, and I still need to work. If I take them at night, I'm very groggy and foggy in the morning and I'm still hurting when I wake up, I just sleep through it I guess. When I wake in the morning, I can barely walk for the first 10-15 minutes. My legs, knees, ankles and feet are very painful in the morning. The pain subsides, but it doesn't go away. My onco says it is arthralgia. When this ride started in Feb 2014, I had only a "pinched nerve type pain" in one spot in my back. Now I have pain in my whole back, all my joints, legs, and today, my right arm (treatment was last week). I have treatment every 4 weeks, and at this point in time it is taking about 3 weeks to "fully" recover after treatment (by that I mean, pain is tolerable enough that i can ignore it) and then I spend that last week just tired and dealing with getting un-constipated. Have you ever changed or stopped treatment because the side effects became unbearable? Advice and personal experiences are so very welcome. I know I don't post a lot, and I'm sorry. I never know what to say, but I read everything. Dx 7/7/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 4/7/2014, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver/lungs/other, Grade 2, 0/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: When Side Effects Become Too Much.... terri-c pajim

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2015 03:17PM terri-c wrote: l've always had problems with medications, usually the less-common side effects, the first time I ever took Nyquil I slept for 2 days straight, scared my mom half to death. The only palliative care docs within 50 miles of me are at the local hospitals and they are in-patient only (which completely blew my mind). I have an appointment with onco on the 30th, and plan to discuss how bad the side effects have become. It's difficult being the weird one. My cancer isn't what they normally see, it has traveled all through my blood, not in my nodes at all, my bone mets are blastic not lytic, I have trouble with meds, I have a very high tolerance for pain - fractured my leg when I was 5, didn't know till the next day, I just kept on trucking. My tumor markers have ALWAYS been in the normal range. On top of all that, my blood work is so wonky they don't know what is normal for me. Motrin doesn't work anymore, the pain meds don't really work, they just make me go to sleep. I feel better when I work, but I am exhausted when I get home. I hope we can figure out something to lessen the pain. Thanks all for the comments, I appreciate them all.
Posts.Title: When Side Effects Become Too Much.... terri-c pajim

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2015 02:02PM terri-c wrote: pajim - I can't be prescribed the sleep drugs, I'm a sleep walker :) My boss is a medical doctor, I spilled it all out to him today, and he thinks I should request a break from treatment for a month or two to let my body heal, then start up again. Then he gave me a rash of crap for not talking to him sooner. Lauralind5 - thank you! It is so nice to know its not just me! Heidi, I get quite a bit of exercise, it is impossible for me to sit at my desk all day long, and we're on the 3rd floor. Plus, I have a 2 year old granddaughter in the house, who I always seem to be chasing around. It does help, but only so much.

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2018 04:26PM terri-c wrote: When my sister first saw the commercial for Ibrance she grabbed the phone and called me. She wanted to tell me about the drug she had just seen and was hoping I could try it because the lady in the commercial appears to be doing so well. I had to explain to my sister that it is advertising, that the person in the commercial likely doesn't have MBC, and that Ibrance, like all of the treatment drugs have side effects that affect different people in different ways. I'm almost 4 years in on Faslodex, and while nothing has shrunk, nothing has grown either. Ibrance will be the next option though, when the Faslodex stops working, or when my body can't take it anymore (I struggle with the side effects).

Posts.Title: I wrote a poem.... terri-c Hummingbird4

Posts.Content: terri-c wrote: When I die, please do not cry I've lived, I've loved, and I've laughed. I raised a family that I'm proud of I made memories that will last. I made choices I'm not proud of And good decisions too I lived my life, not perfectly But I made a difference too. I didn't want to leave I had so much left to do More time with friends and family More love and laughter too. Don't make me a cliché I hate the color pink It was a fight I couldn't win Against a foe that wouldn't shrink. I didn't fight a battle, I wasn't very brave I merely treaded water Trying very hard to stay. My body has betrayed me My God has called me home And you are left behind Though you'll never be alone. I'll still be here tomorrow I'll never be far away I'm in your heart; I'm in your smile Part of me will always stay. Dx 7/7/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 4/7/2014, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver/lungs/other, Grade 2, 0/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2015 12:30AM terri-c wrote: I've started the process to leave my job. April 4 will be 2 years since my diagnosis. I have applied for the ADB for one of my insurance policies that will pay off all of our debt, including the house, and we will only have utilities and insurance left to pay. The first application was denied because my oncology office did not complete the paperwork correctly (they put the statistical life expectancy in the "how much time is left" box), so last week after treatment, I sat down with a PA and we completely updated my records with all of my symptoms and they are submitting that to the insurance company with an amended form explaining the error. Hopefully it will go through, as without this, I am not comfortable leaving my job if the house is not paid off. My husband has a good job, but things will be tight if we still have the mortgage, and I would rather have that money going into savings. My plan is to go out on short-term disability, then transition to long term disability. I have discussed this already with my boss, and his bosses, and we have obtained approval to double fill my position in order to allow me to train my replacement. As soon as I receive the approval on the ADB, we will begin the hiring process for my replacement, I will train them, and then I will start the short term disability. STD will run for 6 months. Once I make the transition to long term disability, I will have to apply for SSDI, and once approved I will apply for Medicaid. In the interim, I will have to continue to pay for my health insurance. It currently costs $100 month (I'm a state employee) and that will last throughout the short term disability, but even with the health insurance credit, it will rise to $460 month while my income will drop to 60% on long term disability. There will be enough funding from the ADB to cover the health insurance payments until I get Medicaid. I never thought I would be "retired" at age 50, and it still feels kinda weird knowing the gears have been set in motion for this to happen. I am looking forward to making this transition. Mostly I look forward to not being so tired at the end of the day that I can keep my house clean and cook more regularly. My husband currently works 6 days per week, once the house is paid off, he will drop to a 5 day work-week and I am thrilled at the idea of having actual weekends with him. Our boys are grown, but we have 2 furry children who love having me home, so the time with them, that includes the energy to walk them and play with them, is a huge bonus also.

Posts.Title: For those who have experienced progression, did you feel it? terri-c leggo

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 04:22PM - edited Mar 14, 2016 04:24PM by terri-c Interesting responses, thank you all. My TM's don't tell us anything, and I haven't had scans since early October, so this will be at about the 6 month mark since the last scans. At first I thought it was a compensation thing, except I don't have a limp on the left hip unless I am having pain, and I haven't had pain in the left hip since December. I keep a calendar of when I take the prescription pain meds and what for (hip, back or head) - it helps me let the onco know when the pain was worse since I only see him every 3 months. The left hip was biopsied 2 years ago, and the biopsy took most of the tumor out, which is why the pain is only sporadic in that hip. I've not convinced myself it is progression, but some of the people around me are concerned it might be, because it is a weight bearing pain (mostly only hurts when I stand/walk, with occasional twinges when I sit too long on that side). I can't remember what it was like to have an energy level above always tired, but I have noticed I'm crabbier than normal lately :)
Posts.Title: For those who have experienced progression, did you feel it? terri-c leggo

Posts.Content: terri-c wrote: So, while I'm still a lurker here, things had been going pretty well for me. My MBC has been stable for just over 4 years now. But yesterday I had to have a colonoscopy because of some symptoms I've had. Doc found 3 polyps that weren't there at last colonoscopy 4 years ago. They were 7mm, 10mm and 20mm, and one had a blood vessel in it. They've been removed and sent to pathology, but I've been doing some research today, and it turns out that though it isn't common for MBC to spread to the colon, it does happen. Have any of you experienced mets to your colon? If so, how was it dealt with after removal? Any information you can provide would be appreciated. The case reports I've read online are interesting, but purely clinical perspectives, and I would rather have the personal perspective. Dx 7/7/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 4/7/2014, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IV, metastasized to bone/liver/lungs/other, Grade 2, 0/9 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 24, 2015 10:41AM terri-c wrote: Woohoo, some ranting! I HATE when people tell me about their friend's cousin's dog's mother's uncle who had the SAME THING and died. I also HATE when people tell me their friend's cousin's dog's mother's uncle cured their cancer with marijuana, with music and lemon juice, with a a good slap to the head with a chair, etc. I know these people mean well, but they don't do the research, so they don't know what they are talking about. Personally, I feel some people who offer unsolicited advice about something they know nothing about just need a high five, to the face, with a brick. And telling me about someone who died? Seriously? I'm in treatment to live as long as possible. I'm in a support group where people I care about die, and I grieve them. Why would anyone think its ok to nonchalantly tell me about people who died of cancer, and think that I want to hear that??? Can they not see that it is depressing? I hate the color pink, and I hate the cliche gifts. My family and friends know not to give me those things. The things I have been given in the past are boxed up. I do not need any reminders. I have found that I have a lot of tolerance for other people's drama because it gives me something to laugh about and focus on so I don't worry about me. BUT, when I'm "recovering" from treatment, and my a$$ is sore, and my head hurts, etc....don't call me, I'll call you. I don't answer the phone, ignore everyone on facebook, and generally have no tolerance for anyone else's "problems" because my own problems are at the forefront and I just can't deal with nonsense when I'm hurting.
Posts.Title: Anyone else need to vent? Rseman NYCchutzpah
